description: Master CDNs to deliver content at the edge, reducing latency and offloading your origin servers

slides.title: What is a CDN?
slides.content:
# Content Delivery Networks (CDN) ğŸŒğŸš€

A network of servers distributed globally that cache and deliver content (images, JS, CSS, Video) to users from a location closest to them.

slides.title: Reducing Latency
slides.content:
# Speed of Light ğŸš€âœ¨

Without a CDN, a user in Tokyo has to wait for data to travel from your server in New York (~200ms round trip). With a CDN, they get it from a Tokyo data center (~10ms).

slides.title: Origin vs Edge
slides.content:
# Layered Delivery ğŸªœ

- **Origin Server**: Where your actual backend and files live.
- **Edge Server**: The CDN's caching nodes located in hundreds of cities worldwide.

slides.title: The First Request
slides.content:
# Cache Miss ğŸ”

1. User requests `script.js` from the edge.
2. Edge doesn't have it (Miss).
3. Edge fetches it from the **Origin** and caches it.
4. Second user requests it? (Hit) -> Fast!

slides.quizQuestion: What is the primary technical benefit of using a CDN?
quizOptions: Replacing the need for a frontend framework
slides.title: CDN Quiz
slides.content: Core purpose.

slides.title: Offloading Origin
slides.content:
# Scaling Power ğŸ“ˆ

CDNs handle 90%+ of your traffic. This means your origin server doesn't need to be giant and expensive, as it only serves the CDN, not the millions of users directly.

slides.title: Anycast Routing
slides.content:
# Magic IPs ğŸª„

CDNs often use **Anycast**, where many servers around the world share the same IP address. The internet's routing protocol (BGP) automatically sends the user to the closest server.

slides.title: Dynamic Content Caching
slides.content:
# Not Just Static ğŸ”„

Modern CDNs can cache API responses (JSON) if you set the right `Cache-Control` headers. This makes even dynamic sites feel instantaneous.

slides.title: DDoS Protection
slides.content:
# The Shield ğŸ›¡ï¸ğŸ’¥

CDNs act as a massive buffer against Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks. They can absorb millions of malicious requests per second without your origin even noticing.

slides.quizQuestion: In a CDN context, what is an 'Edge Server'?
quizOptions: A server with a very sharp design
A server strategically placed near end-users to deliver cached content
The server where you edit your code
slides.title: Terminology Quiz
slides.content: Architecture roles.

slides.title: WAF at the Edge
slides.content:
# Intelligent Filtering ğŸ§ ğŸš§

Most CDNs (Cloudflare, Akamai, AWS CloudFront) include a **Web Application Firewall** (WAF) that blocks SQLi, XSS, and bot traffic before it reaches your server.

slides.title: Image Optimization at the Edge
slides.content:
# Transformation ğŸ–¼ï¸âœ¨

Modern CDNs can automatically convert your JPEGs to WebP and resize them based on the `User-Agent` string of the browser making the request.

slides.title: Push vs Pull CDN
slides.content:
# Ingestion Strategies ğŸ”„

- **Pull**: CDN fetches content from origin automatically when requested (Most common).
- **Push**: You upload files directly to the CDN storage (Best for giant video files).

slides.title: Purging the Cache
slides.content:
# Immediate Updates ğŸ—‘ï¸âœ¨

When you deploy a new version, you must use the CDN's **Purge API** or a unique versioned URL (Cache Busting) to ensure users don't keep seeing old versions.

quizOptions: A way to speed up the database
Forcing the CDN to delete its cached version of a file and fetch a new one from the origin
slides.title: Invalidation Quiz
slides.content: Keeping data fresh.

slides.title: Shared CDNs (Google Fonts)
slides.content:
# Community Cache ğŸ¤

Using a common CDN URL (like `fonts.gstatic.com`) used to be popular because if a user visited another site with the same font, it was already in their cache. 

> [!WARNING]
> Most modern browsers have "Cache Partitioning", making this trick less effective for privacy reasons.

slides.title: Compression at the Edge
slides.content:
# Brotli for All ğŸ—œï¸

Even if your origin only supports Gzip, a CDN can decompress it and re-compress it using **Brotli** for the end user.

slides.title: Lambda@Edge / Workers
slides.content:
# Logic at the Edge ğŸ§ª

You can run small snippets of code (Edge Functions) directly on the CDN nodes. Great for A/B testing, authentication, or small header modifications.

slides.title: Multi-CDN Strategies
slides.content:
# High Availability ğŸ›¡ï¸ğŸ†

Giant companies use multiple CDNs simultaneously. If one provider (e.g., Fastly) goes down, traffic is automatically routed to another (e.g., CloudFront).

slides.quizQuestion: Does a CDN replace your actual web server (Origin)?
quizOptions: No, it acts as a caching layer between your server and the user
